metadata.title: The Toxic Star Performer
metadata.subtitle: Lite
metadata.description: A high-performing individual begins eroding team culture. You must navigate results, boundaries, and long-term team health while balancing courage, system thinking, and psychological safety restoration.
metadata.hint: Tests your systemic leadership, boundary-setting courage, psychological safety intelligence, and accountability consistency under pressure.

dimensions.label: System Leadership Thinking
dimensions.description: How you prioritize long-term team health over individual heroics.

dimensions.label: Courageous Standards
dimensions.description: Your ability to set firm behavioural boundaries even with star performers.

dimensions.label: Psychological Safety Intelligence
dimensions.description: How you sense, respond to, and rebuild psychological safety across the team.

dimensions.label: Accountability Consistency
dimensions.description: How consistently you enforce expectations regardless of performance level.

scenes.label: Scene 1
scenes.title: The Standup Signal
scenes.body: The morning standup ends. The star performer highlights their ahead-of-schedule progress and subtly implies the team should "move faster." The air gets heavy; a few teammates stop engaging.
scenes.tip: Your first response influences whether people feel safe to speak up.

options.label: A
options.main: Praise the milestone and move the meeting forward.
options.desc: You maintain momentum but ignore the cultural impact.

options.label: B
options.main: Acknowledge the win, but shift focus to shared dependencies.
options.desc: You redirect the room back to collective progress.

options.label: C
options.main: Invite another teammate to share their blockers.
options.desc: You re-balance voice in the room.

options.label: D
options.main: End the standup early and plan to handle this privately.
options.desc: Avoids conflict but sidelines immediate psychological safety.

scenes.label: Scene 2
scenes.title: The Avoidance Pattern
scenes.body: Two teammates quietly request to be removed from a shared task with the star performer. They claim efficiency, but their tone reveals discomfort.
scenes.tip: Avoidance is a symptom of systemic stress.

options.label: A
options.main: Approve the change to reduce friction quickly.
options.desc: Short-term delivery takes priority over structural health.

options.label: B
options.main: Ask them to resolve the issue directly with the star performer.
options.desc: You promote ownership but avoid investigating the root cause.

options.label: C
options.main: Pause changes and explore what's really happening.
options.desc: You step into systemic leadership and diagnosis mode.

options.label: D
options.main: Assign full ownership of the task to the star performer.
options.desc: You isolate the tension instead of resolving it.

scenes.label: Scene 3
scenes.title: The One-on-One
scenes.body: In a private check-in, the star performer says, "I hit my targets. If others can’t keep up, that’s on them." They see results, not impact.
scenes.tip: Behavioral boundaries matter as much as performance standards.

options.label: A
options.main: Focus only on outputs and reinforce their speed.
options.desc: Performance praised at the cost of culture.

options.label: B
options.main: Suggest that collaboration helps team success long-term.
options.desc: You offer a soft nudge without accountability.

options.label: C
options.main: Name the behavioral impact and set clear expectations.
options.desc: Direct, courageous, and system-first.

options.label: D
options.main: Warn them that complaints are emerging.
options.desc: Accountability through implied escalation.

scenes.label: Scene 4
scenes.title: The Team Temperature
scenes.body: Team creativity dips. Conversations feel cautious. People optimize for safety, not excellence.
scenes.tip: Psychological safety is a leading indicator of long-term performance.

options.label: A
options.main: Push harder on goals to re-energize performance.
options.desc: You raise pressure instead of addressing root fears.

options.label: B
options.main: Run a team reset session on collaboration norms.
options.desc: You take systemic action to restore culture.

options.label: C
options.main: Ignore the signals until performance drops.
options.desc: A reactive approach that risks deeper cultural damage.

options.label: D
options.main: Remove the star from cross-team work.
options.desc: You reduce impact radius but avoid deeper correction.

scenes.label: Scene 5
scenes.title: Pressure From Above
scenes.body: Your manager remarks: "Whatever you're doing — don't break it." Results are visible; culture is not.
scenes.tip: Leaders often reward the visible, not the sustainable.

options.label: A
options.main: Interpret this as permission to let culture issues slide.
options.desc: Short-term comfort over long-term integrity.

options.label: B
options.main: Raise the cultural risks despite strong numbers.
options.desc: You display leadership courage and systemic awareness.

options.label: C
options.main: Ask for managerial support to reset expectations.
options.desc: You seek alignment to drive sustainable culture change.

options.label: D
options.main: Say nothing and attempt to manage it alone.
options.desc: You act but without strategic support.

scenes.label: Scene 6
scenes.title: Shadow You
scenes.body: A quiet truth surfaces: part of you likes having a star. It boosts performance — and your reputation. Confronting them risks discomfort and outcomes you can't control.
scenes.tip: This is a mirror for your real leadership intent.

options.label: A
options.main: Accept the trade-off. Results justify the risk.
options.desc: Comfort and performance overshadow culture.

options.label: B
options.main: Delay until damage is undeniable.
options.desc: Avoidance disguised as caution.

options.label: C
options.main: Admit that you’re avoiding discomfort and need to act.
options.desc: You choose responsibility over ego protection.

options.label: D
options.main: Blame the team: they should adapt.
options.desc: Shifts responsibility away from systemic leadership.

scenes.label: Scene 7
scenes.title: Final Door
scenes.body: Your next move will define how success works on your team. Not for one person — for everyone.
scenes.tip: This ending reveals your culture-performance balance under pressure.

options.label: A
options.main: Make collaboration a formal performance expectation.
options.desc: You hard-wire systemic excellence and cultural clarity.

options.label: B
options.main: Create parallel tracks: solo excellence and team delivery.
options.desc: A hybrid compromise that maintains options but diffuses standards.

options.label: C
options.main: Keep expectations implicit and manage tensions case-by-case.
options.desc: Flexible but fragile, reliant on your continuous intervention.

options.label: D
options.main: Let results overshadow culture until issues are undeniable.
options.desc: You choose short-term comfort over systemic stewardship.

growthSuggestions.text: Your strategic awareness is strong, but your boundary-setting can be clearer. High performers need firm standards too.
You prioritize results, but restoring psychological safety will unlock deeper team performance.
You attempt courageous action, but consistency is where trust grows. Apply standards evenly across roles.
Consider shifting from individual performance focus to system-first leadership. Long-term excellence depends on collective strength.
Your leadership shows promising balance. Continue refining how you hold high performers accountable while elevating the whole system.
